Award.AwardTitle: International Mind, Brain and Education Society (IMBES): 2020 Biennial Conference
Award.AbstractNarration: The International Mind, Brain, and Education Society (IMBES) conference has taken place every 2-3 years since 2007. IMBES aims to facilitate cross-cultural collaboration in biology, education, and the cognitive and developmental sciences. The IMBES meeting is an opportunity for scholars and educators to come together to engage in reciprocal dialogue about research and practice. Researchers investigating learning processes have the opportunity to share results with educators and receive feedback on the translational opportunities for the research. Educators can update their understanding of the cognitive and neural bases of learning and impart their knowledge of efficacious techniques, tools, and classroom practices with researchers. This type of interaction between researchers and practitioners is crucial for generating research that contributes to usable knowledge for education. This conference aims to assess the degree to which scientific ideas are ready for the classroom, consider the extent to which further educational research is still required, evaluate the potential of current research in meaningfully shaping pedagogy, and recognize opportunities to use the classroom to challenge the robustness of research.<br/><br/>This award to Temple University will provide partial support for the International, Mind, Brain, and Education Society (IMBES) conference to be held in Montreal in June 2020. This award will specifically support teacher practitioners from the U.S. to attend the conference and learn more about educational neuroscience and its potential implications for practice. The teacher practitioners will also have opportunities to share with researchers the nature of effective educational practice. The project is supported by the Discovery Research preK-12 program, which supports research and development efforts to improve STEM teaching and learning in the U.S.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bringing together researchers, educators, policy makers and students, the IMBES Conference aimed to bridge the gap between research and practice in the field of education. Providing opportunities for the sharing of best practices and updating understanding of the neural bases of learning, the IMBES Conference had an agenda that encouraged cross-talk between researchers and educators, a key component when it comes to translating findings from the research setting to the classroom and vice versa. The major goal of the project was to increase the attendance at the conference by generating interest in the conference proceedings and, ultimately, in the field of mind, brain and education.

 

The original plans for the IMBES meeting in 2020 and for using the NSF funds were iteratively revised to address the delays and challenges of the COVID pandemic.

 

Our first decision was to hold the central portions of the 2020 program as a series of virtual presentations over the summer of 2021. The series spanned two months and included seven presentations from various award winners who were planning on presenting at the canceled 2020 conference. These award winners included Dr. Mary Helen Immordino, Dr. Paige Harden, Dr. Elena Grigorenko, Dr. Michael Skeide, Dr. John Gabrieli, Dr. Niko Steinbeis, Dr. Kimberly Noble, Dr. Melina Uncapher, and Dr. Courtney Pollack. Each of the seven sessions included a range of 40-130 attendees and active question and answer discussions. All of the sessions are available on the IMBES youtube channel. We also included trainee research pitch presentations to highlight IMBES trainee research among the seven sessions. Research pitches were brief, five-minute videos of completed or in-progress research conducted by trainees in our community. The trainee then participated in the virtual conference series to participate in the active question and answer discussions. Attendance was free. The 2021 IMBES virtual conference allowed society members, both trainees and established, to reconnect after an uncertain and challenging year.

 

Our second session was to plan a new program for 2022. The meeting remained in Montreal to fulfill our hotel contract. The full program is available at https://imbes.org/resources/IMBESConferenceProgram_2022_FA.pdf 

With NSF support, we were able to offer travel support, up to $2,000 per person. We gave awards to 33 conference attendees using this grant, 44 in total using other funds. The text of our call was as follows

 

Overall, the conference attendees came from 16 countries: Austria, Belgium, Canada, Chile, France, Germany, Israel, Japan, Netherlands, Singapore, South Africa, Spain, Switzerland, Taiwan, United Kingdom, United States. NSF sent Lori Takeuchi who was able to speak to attendees about NSF programs and opportunities.
